Sequence Information.Peptide Name: Microcin B (Gly-rich; McB, thiazole/oxazole modified microcins TOMM, natural AMPs; bacteria, prokaryotes)

Literature Information.Literature:
Chemical modification:  post-translational modifications of GSC, GCS, and GCS triplets led to fused heterocycles in three locations.MOA:bacteria:E. coli: These fused heterocycles could contribute to the binding to DNA gyrase-DNA complex, the likely target of MccB. Without fused heterocycle at site B, the peptide is inactive.Activity: Active against E. coli BL21 DE3 (MIC 0.06 uM).SAR: removal of unmodified C-terminal amino acids of McB, which has no effect on fused 
33 heterocycles, substantially reduced activity in vivo and in vitro. Further, even non-conservative point substitutions in the last McB amino acid influenced peptide activity by simultaneously decreasing uptake and ability to inhibit the gyrase.Updated 10/2024
Literature Information.Author: Shkundina I1, Serebryakova M, Severinov K.2014
Literature Information.Title: The C-terminal part of microcin B is crucial for DNA gyrase inhibition and antibiotic uptake by sensitive cells.
